In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

In Julia, you can write the `wrap_string` function as follows:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::AbstractString; text_width::Int = 10)
    words = split(text, r"(\s+)")
    lines = String[]
    current_line = ""

    for word in words
        if length(current_line) + length(word) + length(" ") > text_width
            push!(lines, current_line)
            current_line = word * " "
        else
            current_line *= word * " "
        end
    end

    if length(current_line) > 0
        push!(lines, current_line)
    end

    join(lines; "\n")
end

# Example:
text = "This is a long string that needs to be wrapped with a maximum text width of 10 characters. The string contains multiple words and should be wrapped correctly."
println(wrap_string(text))
```

This `wrap_string` function splits the input text into words using a regular expression pattern, then iterates through the words to check if the current line length would exceed the text width. If so, it pushes the current line to a list of lines and starts a new line with the next word. Finally, it joins all the lines with a newline character and returns the wrapped text.
